reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of Sexual and Reproductive Health Services to Displaced Persons and Host Communities in Sittwe Township in Rakhine State

description.narrative:
The project, Improving Sexual and Reproductive Health Services to Displaced Persons and Host Communities in Rakhine State, aims to contribute to reducing maternal mortality and morbidity by expanding access to sexual and reproductive health care as set out by the Myanmar Humanitarian Response Plan 2017. Key Objectives of project are to: 1. Improve access to sexual and reproductive health services for displaced persons and host communities. 2. To reduce unmet need for contraception and unplanned births by increasing access to contraception. 3. To empower women, families and communities to claim and exercise their right to access sexual and reproductive health services.
Prior to the most recent wave of events in Rakhine State from August 25th, access to health facilities and skilled health workers was already extremely low. According to the 2015-2016 Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), Rakhine State was the state/region with the highest percentage of women to not receive any ante-natal care and where less than one in five women give birth at health facilities. Inter-communal conflicts and armed conflict in Rakhine State have further exacerbated tension contributing to fear and mistrust which affect service-seeking behavior, while also prompting the closure of some facilities and suspensions in the delivery of health services, thereby further limiting access to quality sexual and reproductive health services. Delivering a minimum initial package of sexual and reproductive health services including provision of post-rape care, and meeting unmet need for family planning will contribute toward ensuring that the 15% of currently pregnant women who experience complications each month are more easily able to access care, and to preventing unwanted pregnancies, among other outcomes. UNFPA in collaboration with Myanmar Medical Association (MMA) will work closely with key stakeholders to strengthen the delivery, coordination, and management of SRH services in order to improve effectiveness and efficiency of the health system. The programme will deliver a minimum package of SRH services to 30 Rakhine villages, 2 Rakhine camps and 5 Muslim camps in Sittwe. The villages and camps were selected in coordination with other health implementing agencies in Sittwe (IRC, Mercy Malaysia and MHAA etc) providing primary health care services to avoid duplication and ensure the broadest coverage of services in Sittwe township.

receiver-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
